10.title: Hospital Transports; A Memoir Of The Embarkation Of The Sick And Wounded From The Peninsula Of Virginia In The Summer Of 1862
10.description: The United States Sanitary Commission (USSC) was a private relief agency created by federal legislation in June,  1861, to support sick and wounded soldiers of the U.S. Army during the American Civil War. It operated across the North, raised an estimated $25 million in Civil War era revenue (assuming 1865 dollars, $386.47 million in 2016) and in-kind contributions to support the cause, and enlisted thousands of volunteers.  It may be viewed as a precursor to the Red Cross.   Frederick Law Olmsted (1822 – 1903) was an American landscape architect, journalist, social critic, and public administrator.  Olmsted took leave as director of New York’s Central Park to work as Executive Secretary of the U.S. Sanitary Commission,  in Washington, D.C. He tended to the wounded during the American Civil War. In 1862 during Union General George B. McClellan's Peninsula Campaign, Olmsted headed the medical effort for the sick and wounded at White House in New Kent County, where there was a ship landing on the Pamunkey River. - Summary by david wales
